description.narrative: CARE will be implementing all GBV, Protection and Shelter activities under results 2 and 4 and CARE will also support Oxfam and CEFORD to mainstream protection and GBV in their actions. Another important value that CARE adds is its large scale operations in SouthSudan and its deep knowledge of prevailing sociocultural norms and gender issues in South Sudan as evidenced by CARE's recently published study (see Inequality and Injustice: the deteriorating situation for women and girls South Sudan's war. A Progressive Gender Analysis: 2013 - 2016). This is invaluable knowledge to ensure effective humanitarian actions with refugees inside Uganda. CARE's presence in South Sudan also means it has firsthand information on the evolving conflict inside South Sudan, ensuring the consortium can be prepared to respond inside Uganda. While this is also true for Oxfam, the fact that our agencies work in different part of South Sudan is a considerable advantage

participating-org.narrative:
CARE was founded in the United States in 1945 to send #CARE packages# # packages of food and basic supplies # to millions of peoplein Europe in danger of starvation following World War Two. Some 100 million CARE packages reached people in need during the next two decades, first in Europe and later in Asia and other parts of the developing world. Britain received its last CARE packages in 1955. Initially we continued to focus on food aid, but in the 1960s we expanded our remit to set up pioneering primary health care programmes. In the 1970s, we responded to massive famines in Africa with both emergency relief and long-term food security and sustainable farming programmes. In the following decades, we increasingly took a #rights-based# approach to development # recognising that poverty is often caused by the absence of rights, opportunities and assets, due to social exclusion, marginalisation, and discrimination. We also started focusing on women#s empowerment, recognising from our decades of poverty-fighting experience that women are key: by empowering women, entire families and communities can be lifted out of poverty. Originally CARE stood for Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, but in 1993 this was changed to Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere. Today, CARE is one of the world#s leading global poverty-fighting organisations, supporting hundreds of development and humanitarian aid projects in more than 70 poor and developing countries around the world. 1. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? In 2015-16,CARE reached more than 80 million people through our development and humanitarian projects and initiatives. The figures below are for the number of direct participants that CARE reached through our projects last year (2015-16). These are people who are directly affected by the problem(s) that a CARE project seeks to address, and whoare directly involved and actively engaged in project activities or are receiving services/goods/resources from CARE or through a CARE partner organisation. Humanitarian aidprojects and initiatives: In 2015-16, CARE implemented 371 humanitarian aid projects and initiatives, which reached over 11 million people directly. # Camp management and coordination: 548,000 people # Education: 105,000 people # Food and nutrition security: 4.1 million people # Gender-based violence: 632,000 people # Health (other than SRMH): 1.2 million people # Livelihood recovery: 1.4 million people # Protection: 664,000 people # Sexual, reproductive and maternal health (SRMH):282,000 people # Shelter: 751,000 people # Water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH): 4.9 million people Notes: Figures are rounded to the nearest 0.1 million or to the nearest 1,000.
In responding to a humanitarian crisis, CARE may provide more than one type of assistance to an individual person affected by the crisis. For example, we might provide food assistance and water assistance to the same individual. The figures for each sector or thematic area show the number of people we directly assisted in that sector orthematic area, but adding the sector figures together would involve some double counting, and therefore gives a bigger figure than the actualnumber of individual people reached by our work.
Development projects and initiatives: In 2015-16, CARE implemented 764 long-term development projects and initiatives, which reached over 69 million people directly.
# Agriculture: 1.1 million people # Climate change and resilience: 755,000 people # Conflict and peace-building: 599,000 people # Disaster risk reduction: 665,000 people # Economic development (other than WEE): 785,000 people # Education: 3.8 million people # Food and nutrition security: 19.5 million people #Gender-based violence (GBV): 1.1 million people # Gender equality (other than GBV): 1.8 million people # Health (other than SRMH): 27.4 million people # Infrastructure: 1.5 million people # Natural resource management: 1.8 million people # Participation and good governance: 1.2 million people # Sexual, reproductive and maternalhealth (SRMH): 49.8 million people # Water, sanitation and hygiene(WASH): 2.3 million people # Women#s economic empowerment (WEE): 2.6 million people Notes: Figures are rounded to the nearest 0.1 million or to the nearest 1,000.
CARE promotes sustainable development by tackling the range of inequalities, injustices and lack ofopportunity that keeps people locked in poverty. This means that we can sometimes work with the same individual in more than one sector or thematic area # for example, participants in health projects might also receive water, sanitation and hygiene services or assistance. The figures for each sector or thematic area show the number of participants in that sector or thematic area, but adding the sector figures together wouldinvolve some double counting, and therefore gives a bigger figure than the actual number of individual people reached by our work.
